article_title: Protections for 9/11 first responders face stubborn hurdles
article_text:
Dan Moynihan, 9/11 first responder, talks with Rachel Maddow about the lobbying effort to generate support for the Zadroga Bill to help with the health care of 9/11 first responders. The bill enjoys wide support but needs House Republican leadership,…

The legislation still hasn’t been renewed, and New York legislators have been busy trying to rally their colleagues to pass a long-term extension of the law so those at the mercy of Congress don’t have to worry about their health care disappearing every few years. However, there aren’t many chances to renew the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act – named after a first responder who died in 2006 – before the year ends. There’s the omnibus spending bill – the one that needs to pass if we’re going to avoid a shutdown – or a tax-breaks extension. […]

article_metadata.description: A measure to cover health care costs for 9/11 first responders seems like a no-brainer, but overcoming Republican opposition is proving to be very tough.

nv.title: Protections for 9/11 first responders face stubborn hurdles

article_metadata.abstract: A measure to cover health care costs for 9/11 first responders seems like a no-brainer, but overcoming Republican opposition is proving to be very tough.
article_metadata.news_keywords: Health, Chuck Schumer, Mitch McConnell, New York

article_summary:
Dan Moynihan, 9/11 first responder, talks with Rachel Maddow about the lobbying effort to generate support for the Zadroga Bill to help with the health care of 9/11 first responders.
However, there aren’t many chances to renew the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act – named after a first responder who died in 2006 – before the year ends.
There’s the omnibus spending bill – the one that needs to pass if we’re going to avoid a shutdown – or a tax-breaks extension.
The bill enjoys wide support but needs House Republican leadership,…The legislation still hasn’t been renewed, and New York legislators have been busy trying to rally their colleagues to pass a long-term extension of the law so those at the mercy of Congress don’t have to worry about their health care disappearing every few years.
